This is trying to be nuanced but ends up being slightly misleading, especially with the title. It's easy for anyone to come away from this believing that "bad" posture is good and "good" posture is bad, but that's not how anything works. "Bad" posture is typically a sign of someone accommodating anatomical irregularities/stresses that already exist, but it's part of a feedback loop which frequently DOES exacerbate those issues. "Good" posture isn't necessarily therapeutic for all but it is a necessary harm reduction element for many. The loads being borne by posterior neck and upper back muscles in "bad" posture are objectively serious and problematic -- it's just that enforcing "good" posture isn't the right solution to this for everyone, just a helpful tool in some cases. Generally the underlying problem does need to be resolved and generally it does involve things like increasing movement and correcting sleep positions (especially people using too many pillows).

This isn't a topic that a short can do justice to, and if you're going to present a very short quick overview of some information (which is a reasonable compromise to make sometimes, nobody can go in-depth about every important topic all the time), then it's even MORE important to at least cite sources and tell us where to find more context for your statement.
